title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SALT LAKE CITY — On a night where defense reigned supreme, one man authored an offensive masterpiece for the ages. Karl Malone, with a Herculean performance that defied the era’s grinding pace, powered the Utah Jazz to a commanding 106-79 victory over the Vancouver Grizzlies in 1997.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was “The Mailman’s” night to deliver. While the Grizzlies’ defense scrambled, Malone was unstoppable, operating with a brutal efficiency from every corner of the court. He poured in a game-high **47 points**, a monumental tally in a contest where the final score barely cracked triple digits for the winning side. Malone didn’t just score; he dominated, muscling his way to the rim and hitting with a marksman’s precision from mid-range.

His supporting cast provided the perfect complement. John Stockton, the maestro of the offense, dished out **13 assists**, many of them finding Malone in perfect rhythm. Jeff Hornacek added **16 points**, stretching the floor and capitalizing on the defensive attention his legendary teammate commanded.

The Grizzlies, overwhelmed by the Utah juggernaut, had no answer. Shareef Abdur-Rahim fought valiantly for his **16 points**, but Vancouver’s offense sputtered against a locked-in Jazz defense, shooting a frigid 36.6% from the field.

But the story was singular, written in the sweat and power of Karl Malone. In a game won by 27 points, his 47-point eruption wasn’t just the difference; it was a historic statement, a reminder of the sheer, unstoppable force that would carry the Jazz to the NBA’s summit.
